description.narrative:
The Niger Delta Budget Monitoring Group (NDEBUMOG) was conceptualized and founded in July 2005. The organization is registered at the Corporate Affairs Commission (CAC) in Nigeria and holds a Special Consultative Status with the Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) of the United Nations. From the organization#s inception till date, we#ve contributed significantly to Nigeria#s and international development processes, either; through international development#s connectors, research/trainings, legislativelobbying, capacity building of stakeholders on public procurement, budget analysis, budget monitoring/tracking, basic economic literacy, shadow budgeting, tracking of illicit financial flows, communally centered capacity for gender justice, fiscal equity,along with campaigns and propagation of inclusive (participatory) budget, fair and justifiable taxation and remediation of audit gaps in Nigeria#s extractive and solid minerals sector. NDEBUMOG is among key civil society organizations# in Nigeria that works on fiscal governance, through programmatic, institutional and (collaborative strategic) synergies with ACAs and other agencies of the governments at every tier in Nigeria. On the strength of the above, we were engaged by the Federal Government throughthe Budget Office of the Federation (BOF) as sector#s expert of the Medium-Term Sector Strategies from 2008 to 2011. NDEBUMOG was assigned to the Federal Ministry of Defense in 2008, and Federal Ministry of the Niger Delta Affairs in 2009, 2010 and 2011respectively. However, till date, NDEBUMOG engages the government (generically) in the MTSS/MTEF processes; through different strategies and approaches, as it pleases the government#s in power, as the government tries to keep date with extant provisions of the Fiscal Responsibility Act. NDEBUMOG was also invited by Nigeria#s Economic Summit Group to the 14th Nigeria#s Economic Summit in 2008, which was to be among session#s discussants that discussed and interrogated the topicality of Nigeria#s belated #Vision 2020#. During the session in reference, NDEBUMOG informed the audience (bluntly) that, such a #vision# would not be realized in Nigeria, due to lack of reliable statistical data and chronic fiscal disequilibrium. The Power of Voices Partnership (PvP)is an influencing programme with the Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The programme FAIR for ALL led by Oxfam Novib is five year long initiative implemented jointly with consortium members Huairou Commission, SOMO and Third World Network-Africa (TWN-Africa) aimed at supporting and collaborating with people’s rightful demands towards companies, governments and multilateral organizations for economic, social and environmental justice, promoting global trade and value-chains that are fair for all. The main focus of the FAIR for ALL programme proposal is to support and strengthen CSOs to play theirdiverse roles; as educators, mobilizers, creators and watchdogs to make trade and value chains FAIR for ALL.
In Nigeria, FAIR for ALL programme aims at strengthening capacity and raising awareness about the socio-economic costs associated with the Nigerian extractives sector, while advocating for improved governance to ensure that firms in the sector operate in a manner that respects human rights and is conflict sensitive. In addition, the programme will influence policy debates and initiatives to ensure sustained and prudent management of tax revenue and other revenues from the extractive sector, and promote accountability in delivering public services.
The Nigeria FAIR for ALL programme will be implemented by Oxfam in Nigeria and partners, aiming to: 1) Mobilize citizens and strengthen capacities of local organizations to increase the level of accountability of public actors; 2) Monitor state budgets and build strong alliances (in particular with women’s organizations) towards a well-regulated extractive sector, ensuring better management of natural resources, and more transparent public-private deals; and ensure 3) Fair and inclusive trade andfiscal systems, with proper taxation of extractive industries and investment of revenues through pro-poor spending in basic services. These objectives will be achieved by increased knowledge on public finance management, including overall fiscal knowledge and literacy on public budgets and government expenses, and increasing capacity to foster citizens’participation in budget processes. To achieve main objectives of the programme in Nigeria, Oxfam will collaborate with NDEBUMOG.

participating-org.narrative:
The Niger Delta Budget Monitoring Group, NDEBUMOG is a regional non- governmental organization formed in 2005, and works in the areas of budget advocacy, transparency, accountability and anti-corruption in the Niger Delta and Nigeria in general. It has the mission to promote transparency and accountability in the public resource management through pro-poor budgeting and anti-corruption in theNiger Delta and democratic consolidation in Nigeria. Novib and NDEBUMOG started collaborating in 2011 to support small initiative of Deepening Expenditure Line Tracking of States and LGAs within the Niger Delta focusing on mobilizing citizens and building capacity for the expenditure tracking using participatory approaches.
Following the success of the DELT4SLOG1, as reported in the 2012 Narrative report and observed by the toolbox team in March 2013, Oxfam Novib decided to support the planned DELT4SLOG 2 to deepen the achieved outcomes of the project in 2012. The project aims to gather useful budget data for advocacy through desk review and field budget tracking of capital projects in the selected locations, strengthen the capacity of CSOs, NDEBUMOG staff, Journalists and community representatives on budget tracking, and established platforms of engagement in Rivers, Bayelsa and Delta States to hold governments accountable on its stewardship through dialogue with the Legislatures and other government representatives.
